description.text:
Saw one on ebay for $110 bucks and decided to make my own. This is a dual 18650 unregulated box mod. Printed with Robo3D on low quality Parts:
1x 15k Ohm resistor
1x IRLB3034PBF mosfet
1x 12mm short thread/shallow depth momentary push button
1x 22mm 510 connector
2x Negative battery contacts
2x Positive battery contacts For the battery contacts, button, and 510 connector used in this project please visit the links below: http://www.mouser.com/Search/ProductDetail.aspx?R=228virtualkey53400000virtualkey534-228 http://www.mouser.com/Search/ProductDetail.aspx?R=209virtualkey53400000virtualkey534-209 http://www.ebay.com/itm/221944081521 http://www.ebay.com/itm/321977524504

title: Prop Rocket

description.text:
To those who have emailed me about the lack of files.. I'm updating the files please be patient no one is paying me to do this so progress is slow. My printer is also under repair and it will take some time to test my mods. The reason for the mods are to corrects some problems and to back out changes made for the museum challenge as the entry was unsuccessful.
This toy takes advantage of the accuracy with which a 3D printer creates parts to produce a very precise aerodynamic and balanced flying toy that only works well due to the precision of a 3D printer. I'm designing different Prop Rockets for it say tuned :-) bigger faster further!

You will need
  • 4, 2mm dia self tapping screws 10-12mm in length should work. or you can glue it together
  • a 4cm rubber band
  • Some fishing line .7-1.2mm dia ~ 0.8m length
  • If you want to avoid wearing out the plastic in the guide hole get a small metal eyelet. I used a short length of brass tube 3mm dia and glued it in place with super glue.
    Clean off raft (best if printed directly on bed).
    • Look at pictures and assemble as shown. Glue halfâ€™s of shaft together. I used a round file to smooth the running surface in launcher and a small piece of sand paper to smooth the shaft (I print in ABS so this works well) then a little grease in the bearing. Drill out the screw holes if you need to so you don't crack the print. Position shaft in handle and attach the retaining cover.
    Note ensure to pre-wind the rubber band and make sure you wind it the right way "anticlockwise" so the pull cord retracts completely. Thread line through spool either hole and tie. Thread other end through hole in handle then thread it through pull nob and tie a few nots to hold it on. If you pre-wind the rubber band, the line should retract. Now go and playâ€¦ be careful it can easily fly sideways and over a house or two! Note V2 launcher file. I have updated it with a stronger pull knob and fixed the hook :-) New Prop Rocket http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13396 Updating files be patient

description.text:
Was wandering through my Thingiverse likes and saw this beauty: Nickel Stand for role playing portraits - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20656 Looks good, and is even modeled clean and pretty as i'm such a snob about!
(Props to U/Gilgamesh82) My only issue was that it requires glue for assembly -That's kind of a deal breaker for me because I am straight awful with any kind of sticky things (glue/tape/whatever). So I built my own version of it from scratch (based completely off of their design) that requires no glue to get pretty much the same end result. Then I threw together some quick character examples with some sexy typos and boom. It has two back options, a cross beam for support (if printing on paper, probably a good idea) or an open back in case you want to print back sides to your characters - be that their actual back sides or stats (better for card-stock, works with paper but have to be careful you don't wrinkle it). Again a 1" wide by 2" tall picture fits in the frame nicely. Instructions:
1) Print it
2) Snap nickel into the base piece (I used the handle on some scissors to bang it down) - NICKEL IS OPTIONAL, it just adds some nice weight to the piece.
3) Put together the top pieces and slide the paper down from the top. Should fit regular paper or card-stock. Prints with no supports or rafts. Edit #1 - Adjusted model faces and added bat wing front version. While looking at it I realized I should be able to add some decoration to the frame without really altering the print or adding supports. Edit #2 - Added monster front version. Edit #2 - Added horse knight version (then edited again because eyes were too small to print) and axe shield version (supposed to be a dwarf) and goblin version - this one with a lower half decoration as well - LEGS! So those are a few examples of what you can do of the basic frame and it still prints and works. Have fun.

Print any one of the Frame designs and mount it with ordinary wood screws to a wall.  Then either edit the corresponding Insert design and add 3D text and print that, or just print one and apply text or images via paint, labels, etc.  The resulting insert should slide into the frame easily to serve as a sign you can easily change out. Vacant/Occupied, maybe?  Or the name of your assistant, so you can fire him and hire a new one every week?  I plan to use it for my recycling center, to show which thing goes where, but find your own use.  
There are three variations, all in the same form factor.  Open is a simple plaque that slides either direction.  End is just like Open, but has a stop at one end, so when you slide it in from the left, it'll go just so far and stop.  Split divides the frame to hold two smaller plaques, great for having one of them show what's above and the other what's below.  
I also includes a Split which already has an arrow.  (If it's not facing the direction you want, rotate the entire object before adding text!)  
The pictures show an insert modified with text and an arrow that's included in the remix you can find linked from this thing.

Print the frame you want, and one or two of the plaques, after remixing to add letters (or just paint them on later or stick on labels).  These should all print fine without any supports, though you might want a brim to avoid curling.  
Mount the frame with #6-32 flat-head wood or metal screws, then slide the insert(s) into it as desired.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:523003 check the "Remix" section for more... The display-Frame is also the same part as in the original. Case and Lid/Fan/Display Holder part are changed. i also integrated a hinge to work with open case... the Clips are made to Clip the box on a mendelmax Frame with 70mm distance. you can also fix the case with M3x10-12mm screws directly to the extrusions. the hole distance is 50mm. that one hole wich is placed under the arduino mega pcb Needs to be a m3x6-8mm one without a spacer. if the head of this screw is higher than 3mm it touches the pcb!!! be shure to have enough clearance at that Point! with a 60x60x25mm fan you need to lift the mendelmax around 30mm up to get clearance for the fan. if you take a 60x60x10mm one you need 20mm between the extrusions and your table. this Thing is not printed by myself Jet and i guess i dont need one any time... so please if you print one upload a few pics and give me Feedback how the parts fit in the comments. the hinge needs support the way ist done at the moment. hopefully i get an idea of how to get rid of this...

you need a few m3 screws ans nuts. m3x20 and m3x16 in most places. the lid Needs one Long screw, it Needs to be around m3x33mm.
after printing first Mount the Case directly on the Frame or on the Clips. one of this screws is not reachable if you put the arduino mega in first.... m3x20 with no nut on the underside should fit too. the holes in the case are 2.8mm Diameter so the should came out as tight fit for a m3 screw.

description.text:
Everyone knows the Tooth Fairy leaves more money if you present the tooth in a little treasure chest. So here it is, a little tooth treasure chest. 
There are two versions here. top and bottom is a two piece chest suitable for single extruder systems. top_w_hinge and bottom_w_hinge can be printed together with soluable supports to make a chest with a top that opens with a little hinge.
To print the combined part bring both the top and bottom models put together. You can do this in SImplify3D by using "align selected model origins". In the edit menu. I also like to print with the bottom of the chest aligned to the print bed (simplify3D edit->place surface on bed). You can do similar actions with NetFabb or your favorite printing software.

description.text: This is a sort of "orange-peel" extracted from the standard Stanford Bunny model included in meshmixer. The object itself is pretty cool, but we think the really exciting part is the custom support structure. This was generated with the support generator in meshmixer 2.0. Files with support generated for a 5cm and 10cm print are included. The images compare our support with MakerWare support for the larger 10cm model. Ours uses much less material and prints an hour faster! Meshmixer is free, get it here: http://123dapp.com/meshmixer

Download and print! I used the Standard print settings in MakerWare on a Replicator 2, with 0.2mm layer height. Do not scale the model, or there is a good chance the posts will not connect, as they are carefully sized. If you want to scale it, you will have to download meshmixer 2.0 (http://123dapp.com/meshmixer) to create a new support structure. The support was not generated completely automatically. In both cases I had to add some additional struts manually. There is a video describing how to do that here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aFTyTV3wwsE Without adding extra support struts in several places, the larger bunny failed, as part of it was knocked over by the print head. Watch the video above and look carefully at your support. You want to add extra strength to any areas where there is a large volume above a small support structure, or where the posts are very long. (The automatic algorithm will get better at this in the future!) I used the default parameters for the support generator, except for setting the tip size to 0.5mm. The default 0.85mm is very conservative and will require much more effort to remove.

title: Universal Cell Phone Mount / Holder for Motorcycles

description.text:
My customizable design of a cell phone mount for motorcycles. I used super glue (cyanoacrylate) for joining both parts and a piece of Velcro to attach it to the motorcycle handlebar (with a tiny rubber part under it for preventing the frame to slip/rotate along the handlebar - I guess you can also use tiny piece of double-sided tape). As can be seen in the pictures, I used a rubber band for holding the cell phone within the frame (and it doesn't cover the cell phone's usable screen area).
Printed with 40% infill and painted varnish over all the frame to make it strong.

description.text:
This is a basic model for an air-track glider. The idea is that the regular metal gliders are so expensive, yet they would be so easy to make with a 3D printer. This will hopefully help lower the cost of successful physics education, while also opening doors for customization.
I will be making prototypes and adjusting the model, but I would also like feedback from you out there (especially physics teachers and students) on how to make this a more viable product. The data I need is specifically related to necessary mounts (the current model has none) and mass adjustment. Your feedback is necessary to the success of this model!
Be sure to notify me if you have any other ideas to help lower the price tag on education.

Dice with customizable images which are engraved on each side. The size of the dice, the size of the images, the depth of the engraving, the curvature of the corners, and of course the images are all customizable.

To get this to work offline, any image must be converted to a .dat file using the tool at http://customizer.makerbot.com/image_surface. That will output an array of values from 0-1 corresponding to the grayscale values 0-255 of the image. Inverting the colors of the image will ensure that the recessed image gets subtracted from other objects properly. Copy the array to a text file. IMPORTANT: be sure that your file is actually a dat file and not e.g. foo.dat.txt. Some operating systems (like Windows 7 by default) hide the actual extension. Once the dat files are in the same directory as the .scad file, and are named properly the surface() function should work.
The way I prepared my image files was to:
1 Import the image into gimp.
2 Crop the image as tightly as possible
3 Right click on the image: Image>Scale Image
4 With the aspect ratio locked, change the Higher of the width and height to 100 pixels.
5 Right click on the image: Image>Canvas Size
6 With the aspect ratio UNlocked, change the Lower of the width and height to 100 pixels. Click "Center". Click "Resize".
7 Right click on the image: Colors>Brightness-Contrast
8 Increase the contrast to remove the effects of the resize, and get sharper edges.
9 Export the file to jpg/gif/bmp/png (it doesn't really matter as long as the customizer tool can read the file).
10 Open http://customizer.makerbot.com/image_surface in a web browser.
11 Select the file you want to convert. Click "Invert Colors".
12 Copy the array of numbers to a text file.
13 File>Save As. In the drop-down menu "Save as type:" select "All files". This will allow you to actually set the extension to ".dat". Name the file .dat. Your image should now create a surface() as intended. EDIT 9-11-2014: A user noted that the printed dice are not fair with certain infill patterns. Recommend 100% infill. EDIT 2-25-2015: A user reported a server error in customizer if one side is left without an image. Either use a null image for any blank side, or download the code and compile offline.

Customizable chair foot that has a cup to hold a felt pad! Works for any chair with cylindrical legs. Allows you to specify the angle at which the leg hits the ground for perfect contact (most are 10 degrees or so).  A small retaining wall stops the felt from slipping out of place.  
The felt cup allows you to place 1" diameter (or whatever size you specify) round felt pads on the chair. The cup retains the felt so it doesn't slide off.  
I designed this thing because my kitchen table chairs (on tile floor) would always mark up the floor as dirt accumulated under the chair leg. Self-stick felt pads always seemed to slide off. The little plastic protectors you buy in hardware stores (the ones with a nail coming through) would eventually accumulate dirt as well, so did not solve the problem. With this thing you can keep the felt pad right where it's supposed to be, retained by the felt cup. When the felt pad accumulates too much dirt and starts scuffing the floor, it is easy to remove them from the felt cup and replace them. On my floor this only has to be done about once every 4 to 5 months for the chairs we use everyday. Less often for chairs not typically used.

There are two parts: the leg cup and the felt cup. The leg goes in the felt cup and the felt... ok too much detail, sorry.  
A separate bottom and top diameter of the chair leg cup may be specified since many chair legs get thicker from the ground up. Use calipers to measure. I added 1 to 2 mm and that works well on my printer.  
This is printable as-is with no extra supports in the orientation shown (see below for the meaning of the supports option).  
The felt pad diameter and thickness may be changed if your pad is not a standard 1" diameter circle. The rim that retains the felt pad will be about half the thickness of the pad. That's only a couple of mm but that appears to be enough to keep it from sliding. I add a couple of mm to the diameter of the pad cup to make it easy to get the pads in and out.  
You may optionally specify whether or not break away supports are automatically generated on the bottom of the felt pad. I actually printed several chairs with no support before adding this option. My printer can bridge the 1" diameter pretty well, but it comes out nicer if you add the supports.  Use small pliers to remove the supports after printing.  
The angle is used if your chair legs do not go straight up and down (many angle into the floor). For my chairs 12 degrees was perfect. I think most chairs will be good around 10 to 14 degrees. You do not have to be perfect here.  Print one, see if it works, and if so print the rest.  
Note that on my chairs there are different diameters for the front legs vs. the back legs. So be sure to measure both.

A tool stand for precision tools (A Wiha set in particular), designed to be modular. Link as many as you like together using the bridge in between and sides on the ends. I plan to make several other tops for different types of tools, stay tuned. Revised: The pin size is now smaller for a better fit.
Added: Another top that accepts larger handle sized driver sets and specialty tools. Pic's coming soon...

It also appears that it is a thermoplastic polyurethane the same as skateboard bushing and wheels so should be ok if printed solid. In theory you should be able to print some pretty decent wheels in Semiflex.
I think I must have lost some hardness from the quality of the print of my bushing.
Use at your own risk.

title: Prusa i3 Universal Y Carriage Plate

description.text:
This is our Prusa i3 Y carriage upgrade plate. We made it as an upgrade to multiple prusa i3 variations with plywood, MDF or acrylic frames. As we all know, heat radiated by heated bed can cause Y carriage deformation, reducing quality and accuracy of of your print. Material used - 3mm or 1/8" thick brushed and Anodized 6061-T6 aluminum. Plate can support various linear motion bearings - LM8UUs mounted with ties, LM8UUs mounted with 3D printed holders (STL file supplied), SCV8UUs and SC8UUs. Belt holder is standard Prusa i3 part, with 41mm spacing between mounting holes (STL supplied). Additional feature of this carriage is 3 pint adjustment option - plate has middle holes to support it. Please see supplied drawings for details pf mounting options, plate dimensions and mounting hardware part numbers. Please, check out our store, we sell bare plate and complete kit with SC8UU bearings, belt holder and hardware. http://reprapchampion.com/y-plate

title: 28mm or 1-1/8 inch InMoov stand for a chair base

description.text: I'm in the US and although there are already a handful of Inmoov stands out there, I wanted one that would fit into a 5-wheel chair base.  Go to Goodwill or ask your building manager at work for a chair base or a chair with a broken lift.  Pull the clip from the bottom of the chair-lift tube and the inside of the hydraulic cylinder will slide out leaving a wonderful and strong base that is about 1-1/8 inch or 28 mm wide and 8 inches tall.  Go to Home Depot or Lowe's and buy a 1-1/8 inch (28mm) by 4 foot dowel.  This is thicker and stiffer than a broom handle.  Note: this holder does not taper.  It fits snugly, so you might need to sand the dowel a little.  There is a small hole you can drill out to put a screw through the holder into the dowel if you need to.   And when you get your InMoov InMooving, you can throw a couple of those 15 lb hand weights that you haven't used in years onto the base...or if you are a scuba diver, grab your weight belt like I did. I tried to come up with a more universal solution that could be attached in multiple locations and would remove easily, but this will do for now.  This stand is closely based on the "Stand-link for InMoov" by d-oo-b so thank you for that cone idea.  I used 2 shells and 30% infill.  I printed it in PLA and am not sure if it will shrink at all if you use ABS.  C'mon, get your awesome bot off the table!

title: Aluminum Heated Bed Build Plate With 3 Point Level Adjustment

description.text:
Majority of Prusa i3 variations a lacking 3 point adjustment for heated beds. We decided to solve this problem and here is the design we came up with. Advantages of this design are
  • designed for high power silicone heater, instead of PCB heated bed, this allows for 3 point adjustment with one hand
  • compatibility with MK1/MK2/A/B heated beds (you just need to cover top soldering pads with kapton tape, in case you use MK2A/B PCB).
  • compatibility with our Y carriage plates (both 3 point and 4 point adjustment)
    • Plate drawing and assembly drawings are supplied. Check out our store for this aluminum build plate and kits:
    http://www.reprapchampion.com/plate-v2
    http://www.reprapchampion.com/plate-v2-full-kit

remixed_from.title: Baseball Diamond Coaster Holder - for 91mm Coasters

description.text: This is a coaster customizer that I made with the dimensions that were already being used by a few other people. I made one by hand with a Mets logo like the others and then I decided to make a customizer to make it easier to make the rest of the MLB logos.

So, cars sitting in the sun, all metal gear knob...dam u hot aussie sun!
I had my car parked for about 30mins in direct sunlight on a rather hot day. Got in to leave and I couldnt manage to hold onto the gear knob due to the fact that it was glowing red hot from the sun, i burnt my hand because it was so hot.
I've experienced this on a few occasions, but never this bad, so i had to fix it.
I present to you a simple gear knob cooler/cosy.
its a double walled, air gap structure which slips over the DRiFT all metal solid gear knob, it keeps direct sunlight off the knob and has a few vent holes in the bottom for temp/pressure variations due to heat, slightly unnecessary, but why not.
the first revision was slightly too tight, so this rev is slightly larger, its a loose fit over the knob, but it does the job.
It keeps the knob at a acceptable temperature, over the course of the day itll still get hot, but nowhere near as hot as without it!
it may even have warming properties in the colder months in colder climates.
its also glow in the dark so it gets charged during the day, and emits a nice soft blue glow at night!
this is only for the gear knob pictured!

description.text:
This is a mount to hold a cell phone to your Syma transmitter. This allows you to use WIFI capable cameras as a FPV monitor. The cell mount is for a Samsung NOTE 3 in a case. I have also tried a NOTE 5 in a case. And while the NOTE 3 is a perfect fit--which it was designed for--the NOTE 5 in it's case fit with a little elbow grease. I did a little bit of "product testing" to make sure that A) the phone would not fall out and damage a phone that is more "valuable" than the drone (X8C). B) to make sure that if you grab the phone holder, it would not break away from the holder and drop your transmitter. I think that this holder is pretty robust. You could almost say "chunky". With that said, if you don't have a NOTE 3 or are just unhappy with the design, I included the 123D Design file, so that you can modify the mount to your phone or your transmitter--if you are not using a Syma transmitter. The phone weights almost as much as the entire transmitter, so the center of gravity of the transmitter is closer to the base of the antenna. So, I would HIGHLY recommend some type of lanyard. Also, if your case is not as exactly as wide as mine, you can use a rubber band to keep your phone from sliding out. Speaking of phone mounts, I used tophe75's idea for a phone holder but not his file: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:192129. I think his design uses too much plastic and would not work with my mount. If I had a different phone and more time, I would prefer a mount like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1133548
I will leave that up to the end user as I only have these 2 phones to try. The design calls for either 5 3mm x 20mm Pan head/Cheese head machine screws or 5 #4-40 x .75" machine screws (also pan head/cheese head) and 5 matching nuts. With that said, I was able to use only 3 screw/nuts and it was more than strong enough. You can add the other 2 screw/nuts if your holder is not as tight. Also, I used captive screw holders that work for both #4 nuts and 3mm nuts. They are on both the top and bottom so you can have the screw heads point up or down--your choice. As far as material and printing. I printed the two "Horse Shoe" pieces at .3 layer height and 50% infill with 3 shells. You want this piece to be VERY robust. The phone holder takes a lot more plastic and a .3 layer resolution and 10% infill is adequate. I would recommend 3 shells on this part, as the screw that holds this part to the "horse shoe" is transmitting all its retaining force through those 3 shells. I printed a complete set in both PLA and ABS. I think the ABS is a better material for this application but the PLA held up fine. Since PLA is less flexible, the screw interface between the phone holder and the horse shoe mount will break and pull through with rough handling. For the record, both PLA mount and ABS mount were dropped--with NOTE 3 in holder-- and both held up. Lastly, the phone holder could really use a sun shade. There are plenty of cell phone mounts on Thingiverse. You just need to make sure that is can be attached to the mount (16.5mm from edge to screw hold center on the mount). Again, the original 123D Design file is included so that you can make those changes for your phone if you do not have a NOTE series phone. Happy flying!

Printer:

XYZ da Vinci

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

50% on transmitter mount /10% on phone holder

Notes: I printed in both PLA and ABS. ABS is a better choice for this project but if you don't have ABS, PLA will be fine. Use 50% infill and 3 shells on the transmitter mount. You can always add more screws if you find something else you want to mount to your transmitter. 50% will give you something to drill through. Use 10% infill and 3 shells for the phone mount. You also need 5 machine screws and nuts. Either 3mm x 20mm or #4-40 x 3/4in pan head screws. Really, 3 is fine. The other 2 are for insurance purposes. I also recommend sanding the two transmitter mount faces flat--the two that mount together. When the two halves are screws together, there should be no day light between them. My printing leaves a wavy surface that took two seconds to sand flat.

I have noticed a number of people who enjoy collecting miniatures, and I like giving back to the community that has given me so many ideas and shared their own models.  While I wait for the sink bowl to render, I think there are a few I still need to "Like"...
In an attempt to help someone potty train, I had downloaded (from here) and printed a fist-sized toilet with working lid, for all the stuffed animals to use when they needed.  However, this youngster apparently was - correctly, in my opinion - taught that you wash your hands after a visit to the potty.  What followed was my Inbox receiving a "we need a sink" request.  And after my initial sink came an apologetic "do you also have a towel rack?" ...
I hadn't liked my first sink much.  Sharp corners, the drain wasn't deep enough, lack of any kind of soap (yeah, I had started to predict the next requests).  So instead of designing up a new towel rack, I added a swinging towel ring to the side of the sink.  With a snippet of felt through the ring and snapping the base to the bowl, I seem to have appeased the youngster ... for now.
So I give you my mini sink.  The one I modeled it after had wide-set handles for the water, though if anyone has strong feelings about it I'd be more than happy to add a model with rounded/crowned handles.  I enjoy snap-fit models, so I apologize if things get a little snug from time to time.  I often put a 0.1-0.2mm chamfer on connecting points that print on the glass to help with this, though I'm open to suggestions for better ways.
As usual, my STLs tend to be a wee bit on the large side, for which I apologize.  But until someone complains, I'd rather give the higher quality original that I used, instead of a lower-quality model that can fit on a floppy (yes, upon a time we did once use the Save icons to store data).
Actually, for some reason the site doesn't want to render the high-res sink, so I am attaching an STL rendered with slightly better than "Fine" resolution.

None of the Tardises on here were quite what I was looking for, so i decided to make one myself.  
I tried to make it as parametric as possible, but you'll still find some things, such as the depth of the face impression, that are static.    
I'm working on an accompanying insert that will light up the light on top from the inside, I'll add that as a derivative as it develops.  
Let me know if you find any parameters that aren't scaling/re-sizing properly.
EDIT:  Per suggestions from Bluemetal and Tbuser I've added leading 0s to my decimal values and added render() to the face module, so it will now compile(F5) properly.

comments.text: When I run into the too many elements error, I usually get around it by using the render() method around sections of code.  It basically makes part of the code do a pre-render F6 so that it doesn't have to rebuild it for the CSG preview every time you press F5.  In the case of your tardis script, I put a render() in front of the color line in your face() module and now it compiles "quickly" and lets you view the preview when you press F5.

Moving to a cold climate made it necessary for me to have- quite against my will- a snow shovel.  The novelty quickly wore off, and I eventually needed a place to store this shovel where it would not be in the way.  This is the thing I came up with, designed to be held up using 1 inch drywall screws.  It seems to work pretty well.
I made this using my PrintrBot Simple Metal, with a heated print bed and an all-metal Ubis hot-end.  I made it out of Hatchbox ABS, extruded at 70% density and 250c and with the print bed heated to 70c.  It came out very solid and absolutely straight with no warping.

description.text: More safety? Yes, please! Mount a strobe light on your Inspire 1. My 1st experience with designing a piece from nothing. I needed some drawers for my electronic parts so I made this. I will make a module for the spools of wires a bit later I tested this with Wood filament, PTEG, PLA ABS will warp too much for the shelf part, I can probably make more holes to relief the stress.
but I don't need it myself New:
-New drawer with compatible hook for DinRail (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1581801)
-Label holder on separators and increased gap of separator by 0.1mm Previous changes:
  • Is for the printers that are moving and shaking it too much, the middle supports can collapse.
    -Will save about 100g of material over 3.1 at 100% infill.
    -35% it is about 332g of PLA material instead of 376 @ 35% infill.
    -I Print these at 10% total 310g
    -Added some tabs to allow the back to stick better to the base
  • Thicker, easier to remove and reuse separators
    • Notes:
    -Scaling by 1000 may be needed, my units are mm in blender.
    -New design for the drawers, pictures will be updated, this handles can fall off while printing.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Better to print the shelf with the back on the build plate.
If you have a bed that moves be careful with the speed as the mid support mid fall off and destroy your print. The drawers can be printed without issue. The bottom part of the round edge might not stick so well, but it works on my FFCP. If there's a demand I can the drawer make 2, 3 wide or 2/3 high. I plan on adding drawers with spools and a spool rack on top of it.

My Airpump for my laser cutter did not come with the air fitting, and I needed one quickly so I made this.  I printed it in PLA and wrapped some teflon thread tape and screwed it into the compressor.
The compressor gets warm and softened the PLA print.  I had to support the air hose so it did not put a force on this fitting when it was warm,  used it for 3 days in a row so far no leaks.
use at your own risk  :-)

I thought it would be point less to publishing this, but after seeing \"Sumobot Chassis by langfordw\" I said to my self why not. The EEEI Robotic http://ieee.rutgers.edu/robotics/ club at Rutger was inviting all student to joint the line following competition to build a robot from a kit. More detail description of the kit can be found here http://ieee.rutgers.edu/robotics/attachments/069_Kit_Description.pdf. They also made four classed meeting once a week for student who have no skill in soldering or programing to assemble the kit. After the four classes student have two week to prefect their bot before the competition. The kit costs $65, but since I already had Atmega sitting alone in a box I decided to get the kit without the Freeduino for $45. I got chance to use the Atmega and learn how to program it. I could not let this opportunity just pass by.

I made a small website with more detail instructions on it. Also I included short documentation in the zip file about how to build the large printed parts. http://sites.google.com/site/rapidgeneration/line-following-bot

title: SOUTH BEND LATHE MODEL 9C ( 1937-1940 ) 127/100 METRIC TRANSLATION RING GEAR
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Metric Translation gear for cutting metric threads on an imperial leadscrew lathe this was designed for a South Bend lathe model 9C. photo is of 80/63 translation gear as I don't think this 127/100 would fit my present set up need to make another banjo to make it fit. The teeth have 14.5 degree pressure angle
The gear has a DP of 18
The module is 1.411
True involute form The 127 tooth has an designed inside dia of 165mm but ends up about 164mm
The 100 tooth has a designed inside dia of 127mm but ends up about 126mm The 100 tooth ring has 1mm step so it give a gap between the gears so it is 3/8" wide + 1mm
The 127 tooth ring is 3/8" wide which is the width of the standard South Bend gears It's mainly a space problem that dictates which of the translation gears you use, there may be others but these are the common ones that I know of. The 127/100 metric translation gear which gives no errors in the generated pitches.
The 80/63 gives an error of 0.0125%
The another gear set 47/37 gives an error of -0.0212%

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used a 0.3

Infill:

100 %

Notes: The centre I made is of hardwood as that is what I had laying around, but form board or marine ply would probably be a better option.
I turned the timber so that the ABS ring just slipped over then cover with super glue and made sure it ran true before the glue set

comments.text: Thanks for all the gears! I just purchased a South Bend 9CW and it came with only 1 or 2 extra gears for thread chasing. Looking forward to using it!
comments.author: Dr_Romeo_Chair

comments.text:
• 2 Reasons A save on plastic. B more important that the less plastic in the item and shorter print time less likely to have a print failure.

  • After 18 months never had a failure, and I have several machines that use the same gears. Only thing I found initially is the meshing of the teeth, because they are printed they are a bit rough and meshing needs to be set up so they run smooth, i just coated them in grease.
    But one of my other machines the gears had to run dead true, so I made a hob cutter and cleaned the teeth up making them run like fully machined gears.
  • I use Rhino 3d which has a script for designing gears
comments.author: Dr_Romeo_Chair

description.text:
Here is a pendant that contains a hidden heart.  If printed from natural ABS a heart is visible when the pendant is held to a light.  The image at the upper left shows it used as a window ornament.  
It was constructed from the intersection of a heart shaped polyhedron and a hexagonal array of cylinders using openSCAD.  The pendant is about 60 mm in diameter.   
OpenSCAD code is included.

The heart is best printed directly on the build platform.  It was designed to have a single layer of plastic on either side of the heart.  On my Replicator it took about 50 minutes to print using 1 shell and 100% infill.

Please watch this video for more information and to see it in action: https://youtu.be/D6DdESIhi4c Welcome all who are worthy! (Okay I promise that's the only worthy joke I'll make here. There's more in the video though.) :) This is a fully 3D printed Mjolnir. I made it life size. I'm sure it's not the exact dimensions of the movie prop but it's close. It can also be scaled pretty easily. This version of Thor's Hammer is specifically from The Dark World movie. I'll provide the steps for post processing in a lot of detail below, but if you want a higher level look at it, watch the video. I provided two different options for the main part of the hammer. It prints in 2 sections, and they are identical so just print 2 of them. There is a hollow one if you're looking to save a bit of filament (this is the option I took). But I also provided a solid one that will print in a better orientation if you're able to spare the extra filament. The solid option will also provide more weight which could add to the realism of it. I hope you enjoy printing this! :)

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: All of these settings are more or less flexible. The only supports you'll need are for the little slot on the bottom of the bigger portion of it. But they aren't strictly necessary. I didn't use any supports while printing, I just had to do some clean up. I printed at 0.3mm layer height but you could increase that for better details. I was just trying to save some filament. And infill doesn't matter too much here.

Step 0: Print all the parts.
Step 1: Sand the parts down as much as possible. The details on the handle and the outside of the hammer can be pretty hard to get smooth, but do your best. The sides of the hammer should be completely smooth to the touch though. Start with a coarse grit sandpaper in the ballpark of 100 grit. Then move up to 400 or above to get the best results.
Step 2: Glue the parts together. Use the printed pins to hold the parts in place, then apply glue to those pins to adhere them together. I used a Gorilla Glue Two Part Epoxy, glued the parts and held them for a bit until they dried. Then once the parts are together, take a paint brush or something similar to apply the epoxy generously over any cracks or seams you want to cover. Then once the glue has dried completely, sand the areas over seams to get those smoothed down as well.
Step 3: Prime the hammer. We chose to use a black spray primer from Krylon. Coat the hammer at least twice, letting it dry completely in between coats. Just lightly spray across the surface using a normal spray painting technique. Don't stress too much about the detailed areas at this point.
Step 4: Painting the hammer. We used a Hammered Metal spray paint. Specifically silver colored. Apply 3 coats of this, letting it dry completely in between. If needed, you can sand any rough areas in between coats. Just use your judgement on what looks best. The paint should fully cover the hammer.
Step 5: Paint the handle. For this you'll need a paint brush and some brown acrylic paint. Paint the brown on the lower areas of the handle, leaving the silver rings and base of the handle as is. Make use of multiple brushes to get into hard to reach areas. Apply 3 coats of this to get a smooth, but plentiful coverage of paint. You can always go back over the details on the handle with silver paint if you need to.
Step 6: Apply a wash. I won't go into a ton of detail about the wash. You can YouTube "applying a wash to miniatures" if you want more details. We took some silver and black acrylic paint, mix it and watered it down significantly then applied it to the details on the handle and on the sides of the hammer. Use a paper towel or spare paint brush to dab off excess. This will give the recessed areas a more defined shadow.
Step 7: Rough it up. This step involves taking sand paper to the paint on the bulk of the hammer to give it a worn and used look. Go around the edges and just lightly sand it to give it a more textured look. Then take some of your paper towels you used to clean off the wash and lightly dust that darker color across the body for even more texture.
Step 8: Apply a finish coat. You can get some spray clear coat and just spray the whole thing once it's completely dry and done. This will help protect it from damage like scratches to the paint.

description.text:
This is a Syma X8C 6 battery box with snap lid.  I am uploading this at the request of Predator04 for such a box.

Anyways, I think PLA might be a better material for this project.
I am including the 123d Design file.  Play with it all you like.

description.text: A Sh1t Shank I made in TinkerCAD user:Alex Montague

Hello !
Ceci est un pote gobelet en deux parties, le support et deux tailles de pied interchangeable...
Décompresser, imprimer, assembler et accrocher vos gobelets
Bonne impression

Tiny Tank is a small, treaded vehicle, optimized for easy printing and extendability: you can easily design your own components to fit on the tank. A mounting bracket is also provided to house a wireless receiver, like the IDT P9038-R-EVK. A housing for the sender is also provided: so the tank can drive on the sender and charge itself. Everything is fitted together with M3 bolts, which press fit into the openings.
The treads are connected using iron wire, any type will do to make this work. For control I use a Particle Photon, but you can swap this for your own micro controller. The vehicle is powered by 2 9g Fitec continuous rotation servo's, a cheap and easy item to buy. To build a tank you need:
  • 2 x Side Beam
  • 1 x LED Beam
  • 1 x Servo Beam
  • 4 x Wheel
  • 2 x Static Axl Parts 1, 2 & 3
  • 32 x Tread Element
  • 18 x M3 bolts (10mm)
  • 2 x M3 bolts (16mm)
  • Iron wire
  • Each of the IDT mounting parts for adding the IDT Wireless power
    • Furthermore I used:
  • 1 x Particle Photon (buy at https://store.particle.io/)
  • 3 x LEDs
  • 1 x USB power bank
    • To control the tank, I use code on the Particle, in combination with a console application, written in .Net. The Photon connects to the .Net application using a socket and small commands are sent to control the servo's and LEDs.
    This requires a direct socket connection, so connecting to another network segment can require additional configuration. The controls in the .Net application support an XBOX 360 controller, which allows for easy control of the vehicle.

I have been thinking about old cardboard necromunda terrain and wanting to re-create the style of the bulkheads and scifi butresses. The idea was to make the majority of the flat wall & floor panels out of 3mm sheet mdf, with the above corners holding the building together. These proto types files have no internal detail yet, as the building i'm using them for will be a solid object for a warhammer 40K terrain set. However if it works i intend to come back and make of range of corners with even more detailing for making necromunda buildings. More details about my wargames terrain making can be found at: https://terrain4cake.com/, along with in progress and finished photo's of the building with these corners.
Complete building using these corners can be found here: https://terrain4cake.com/2016/04/15/snowy-ruins-40k-terrain-pt5-complete/

Found in milk, bovine β-lactoglobulin is a commercially important whey protein of nutritional value. This is a model of β-lactoglobulin with a fatty acid, palmitate, bound. "β-Lactoglobulin is the major whey protein of cow and sheep's milk (~3 g/l), and is also present in many other mammalian species; a notable exception being humans. Its structure, properties and biological role have been reviewed many times."
--https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta-lactoglobulin One STL file contains a representation of the protein in cartoon form with residues binding the palmitate group represented as spheres (in blue in the images). A separate STL file contains the palmitate group itself (in green in the images). Model based on the Protein Data Bank entry 1B0O:
--http://www.pdb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?pdbId=1b0o Model created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/

title: YASH - Yet another SD Card Holder

description.header: WOW! Yash is yet another SD Card holder!
description.text:
But it has some stunning SPECIAL features:
  • holds up to 9 SD Cards
  • has a slight tilt so Cards won't fall out
  • less material! - print fast and ecological
  • amazing design! - it even has a name on the right side!

New Flex Design, holds SD Cards even if you shake it! Visit Yash Mk2 here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1462065
It works better if you have Flex Filament, so the Cards fit tightly into it!
--- END OF UPDATE --- Whole story:

I had a "normal" printed SD Card holder till today, but the cards were stored upside down. It had a round shape on the bottom (thanks to warping!) so everytime I tried to pick a card, the whole thing turned around. The space between the cards was so tiny, that I picked 2 cards EVERY time. There were a lot of things that upsetted me, so I just HAD TO redesign it. I used my whole creativity to design it, so there was no "power" for a good name :-)

tl;dr: It's just a SD Card rack / holder, designed for my desk. I really like it and wanted to share :-)

description.text: A protective sleeve for the Pocket Operator series of synths. I used velcro around it, but you can use a rubber band, or earbud wires.

When kids start to brush their own teeth, they often put down the toothbrush to put on the toothpaste. With both hands squeezing the toothpaste tube, then more often than not the toothbrush rolls over. Bummer.
With this small tray gadget, their toothbrush is stable and they can put on the toothpaste themselves. Without the toothbrush rolling off and spilling the toothpaste etc etc.
Plus it can be a cool little thing just for them! Adds a positive little item to brushing their teeth :)

hAVE YOU EVER ACCIDENTALLY HIT THE cAPSLOCK kEY WITHOUT REALIZING IT? oF COURSE. eVERY ONE HAS AT SOME POINT OR ANOTHER. pERSONALY. i FEEL LIKE i DO IT ENTIRELY TOO MUCH. sO i HAVE DECIDED TO DO SOMETHING ABOUT IT.
What I have come up with is something I call the Caps Locker. Basically it is a mechanical block designed to slip under the caps lock key on mechanical keyboards, and physically block from being pressed, as long as it is in place.
This thing was specifically designed for my own use with the corsair vengence k70 keyboard. But it should be compatible/usable with most mechanical keyboards, considering the switch sizes is a constant, and key size/shape is typically a constant as well.
This thing may/may not cause the surrounding keys to bind and stick. But in my own experience, it fits perfectly into place with just the slightest bit of sanding and jiggling. In fact, once you manage to seat this thing in place, it's kinda hard to get it to bother surrounding keys.
Obviously compatibility may or may not vary by keyboard manufacturer/model. If you guys have compatibility issues, please comment with more info, and what, if anything you did to make this work. I fully encourage other people to alter/improve this design. But please note the the creative commons, attribution, non-comercial licensing

title: Decorative Triple Incense Burner with ashes collector box and incense bars holder

description.text:
This is a Printable Decorative Triple Incense Burner with a removable collector box, so when you have to empty the ashes, you just have to extract the box as a drawer, clean it with water , and put it on !   
Burn 3 Incense Bars at same time to get an extra flavour to your home :) (you can only use 1 bar if desired!)  
The Triple Incense Burner got a container to hold all you incense bars for future use.  
Very stylished and functional in my opinion.  
Designed on Sketchup, the Source file is published, so you can improve this design!

I printed it with 0.3 mm and PLA.
Use 3 mm of brim for avoid warping.
If the holes are not clean on the end of printing, warm a wire and put it on the holes to clean them. The box is with the exact fitting size, i recommend you to scale the box at 99.5% so it will fit in without having to brush the holder. Enjoy!

Print as many of these things as you want, and arrange to make your own hanging garden for a sunny window.  
You will need to make holes in the models to pass string through to hang them up.  I used superglue to fix the base thingies inside the bottom of each planter to keep them from moving around too much.  I also printed a base thing for the bottom planter too but I scaled it up by 25% to fit.  My bottom planter wasn't fully watertight, but a couple coats of nail varnish sorted that out pretty quickly.
Enjoy!

Drill or melt holes into the sides of the planters.
Fix the base plates into the bottom of the planters.
Tie the planters together however you wish, trying to get them level.
Attach to a piece of wood or something - I tied all the strings to a bamboo pole, and then hung the pole up by a window with little hooks.
Fill with potting soil or other planting medium (I used coir) and add plants.
Carefully hang the contraption up, without dropping the whole thing behind a set of shelves and getting potting soil everywhere :)

remixed_from.author: Tunabarrage
remixed_from.title: ZMR 250 GoPro hard mount 15 degree tilt

description.text:
Quickly tweaked the angle for the camera to 25 Degrees. This allowed me to print without supports on my printer. It weighs in at a total of 20.6gr at 30% fill and 1.2mm shell(ABS). By comparison, The stock GoPro double sided tape mount + clip adapter + The Frame + screw weighed in at 41g!
Kept the inside dimensions as they were so you can insert some PEE sheet around the GoPro to cushion the vibrations then secure it with velcro through the frame.
I suggest brushing the outside walls with acetone to secure the layers. This makes breaking a lot harder. It will also make it shinier, haha.
This is just a 3D Printed plastic version of the Tiffany Sterling Silver Bookmark.

Notes: PLEASE READ BEFORE PRINTING!!!!!!!!!!! Scale along the X and Y for desired scale most likely keep them the same to maintain 2D proportions then scale your z to change the height. I recommend something between 25%-35% on the Z SCALE !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Hearst Tower is a 46-story glass and steel, 858,000 square foot commercial office building for the Hearst Corporation. The building was built within and above the original six-story Hearst office building. The 1928 landmark façade was restored and integrated with the tower. The structural frame, standing 598 feet tall, is enclosed with a panelized glass curtain wall system and stainless steel diagrid cladding. The triangulated steel frame uses 21% less steel than a traditionally framed building, saving 2,000 tons of steel. Click here to learn more about this project:
http://www.turnerconstruction.com/experience/project/6B1/hearst-tower
